comments.body:
Here's my take on the anvil:

I think the "Too Expensive" needs to be replaced with a hard cap of maybe 5 enchantments per item, and the incremental exp cost increase after each repair on the same item needs to be removed.

Exp costs for repairing enchanted items should be more predictable and not as expensive, but adding new enchantments to items should still have an exp cost just like enchanting itself.

Maybe the exp cost would always depend on the amount of enchantments on the item.

Repairing netherite also is currently not viable without Mending, so maybe it should be able to be repaired with diamonds.

YES! I've played in a world for hundreds of hours and it takes a long time just to collect a handful of sherds. I have a large base and would like to decorate it, maybe you could use emeralds or bricks and even the items that the sherds represent.

Put in other more accessible but valuable items with the sherd to create a copy

I don't think it should be crafted with a brick but instead using 4-8 clay balls with the intended sherd to be copied in the middle. With this idea, the original sherd will return to player's inventory and make a new item called a "(Sherd Design) Casting". This new item would then need to be smelted in a furnace to then produce a "copy" of the sherd. This still promotes exploration to find the many types of sherds, but also allows for mid-to-late game auto farming to allow Decorated Pots to be used a lot more often in builds.

by the fact that this post is 1 year old and noone has said anything, i don't think you're gonna recive an answer; I have the same problem and i'm gonna create a mod just for this; in the near future look for a mod called "Enchantment Splitter" or something like that :D

I would strongly agree, but I am not convinced that copper would be best for tools and armor. Copper's uses outside of building seem to be suboptimal, as lightning rods and spyglasses don't seem to have the same amount of utility as tools created with iron or gold such as flint and steel, buckets, compasses, etc.

I would urge the team to consider using Copper as an "amplifier" for enchantments at the enchanting table. When using one smelted Copper ingot with lapis and a tool at the enchanting table, the applied enchantments have their levels increased by anywhere from 1.2 to 2x up to the max limit, so consider maybe Sharpness 2 without copper becomes Sharpness 3 with copper.

I would also suggest that blocks of copper can be used in redstone the same way that redstone blocks are, just not always automatically powered. In this sense, when a copper block receives a redstone current, it functions as a redstone block, but when it is not powered, no current. This can be incredibly helpful to redstone engineers who want to see a piston-movable and switchable power source.

Lastly, I would suggest that copper can be used to supplement minecart travel. Adding copper to rails and powered rails can increase minecart speed by 1.5x or 2x. These can make minecarts a more useful form of travel by increasing their top speed, giving late-game players a more competitive option to fireworks and mending elytra's.

Maybe there should be an engineer villager that buys copper stuff. He could sell redstone components and Data Sheets that show how to build different components and give a brief explanation of their use. Tools and armor won't be a good idea due to where it could possibly be placed on the tier list.
Copper is much better suited for making armor and tools than diamond.
no

copper tools should be just barely worse than iron, but, need maintenance and they would slowly lose effectiveness and degrade faster through weathering, if you maintain them (maybe putting a tool in the off hand, axe in main hand and not looking at a block would have you remove oxidation as is done to blocks)
waxing your gear would pause weathering until you take enough damage / use the tool enough
it is common so cheap but needs a bit of effort to keep it close to iron
This would be more realistic. However, it might make stealing a bit to easy.

Please please please make this a feature! I want to build a library of book & Quill and enchanted books, but I can't see what I've put on the shelf!

I don't think the comment of "making it easier to steal" is a very good point to debate why we shouldn't have it.
Would this require a new kind of trim for each tool (Sword trim, pickaxe trim, hoe trim) or would the same trim work for all tools?
I think that Moment could maybe add a couple new trims but make most of the armor trims work as well.
This is a must have feature.
Villagers will ONLY trade for emeralds. Introducing rubies would be as useless as the current trade of selling diamonds to a blacksmith. hrrm
yes that will bring back memories
I mean it kind of seems cool but why.
WOuld it be a number disk like 11, 13, and 5 or would it have a letter name?
Technically, you already can smelt gear, but you get nuggets in return.
replying to the dude above me, its only for gold things, and the "depending on how used it is, tells you how much ore you get back" doesn't happen, its just 1 nugget a pop (:

Very much agree Sandstone bricks would be amazing.

I would love a set as we have for deepslate. Small bricks big bricks smooth and normal is a fantastic set to work with.
No! Us bedrock players should get the boss bar command if you guys get the camera command!

This thread should have more attention because the Idea is very good!

But you should move the english version up because minecraft is international.
I like the idea of slabs of some kind that fit a grass terrain.

It seems to me that the "Colony" of moss is always the same thickness.
I think it's worth adding layered dirt, sand, foliage. And on these surfaces, the moss layer will be located in one layer. But since leaves, dirt and sand can be layered on top of each other as much as they want, it will look smooth even with moss.

I agree with the rust idea, but maybe not so much with lightning restoring the Iron. Perhaps Iron golems can rust too, like in my idea, but perhaps only in water and rain, and certainly over time. Items can rust too, which would apply negative effects the more rust it has, like -1 damage, or longer attack speed, or perhaps less protection. Maybe even a x2 durability penalty. You can apply honeycombs to Iron Items and other such things on crafting tables, but rust on items can only be removed on a grindstone or anvil.

But rust should certainly be added to Minecraft either way. Makes things more realistic.
For weapons and armor, why not, but the blocks, I don't think it is a great idea...
Let's just assume that in the Minecraft world it is logical for copper to rust and for iron to not rust. I know it does not make sense, but it should not be changed because I use iron a lot!
maybe the mossy deepslate variants could have a sculk look to them
Need more mechanics tied to the wind. For example, the impact on the flight of phantoms, bees, parrots, elytra players; Exposure to boating outdoors.
If this were added, I would that it‚Äôd have some redstone functionality so you can, say, automatically teleport a player to a powdered snow farm to make it function.
Ah, yes very useful. I currently have heaps of copper, so why not find new uses for it?

Shoji is well done in a mod called "Quark".
I think the developers can make an arrow recipe with crystal instead of flint.
Yeah, like water torches, for example !!!
Yeah, like water torches, for example !!!
I recently thought of the idea of having prismarine clusters, similar to amethyst clusters. It would make the guardian temples look more unique. It would also make for a great decorative item.
Minecraft needs this because there is like no point for me to mine copper. But i can make copper blocks, but i want more tools armor and weapons.

I think there should be copper tools and armor so that there is more variety in equipment, plus there is not many crafting recipes for copper and there is quite a lot of copper in Minecraft worlds. When I go mining on Minecraft I get quite a lot of copper.

Now that you mention it, that IS really annoying. I would like to also include stone and Purpur in this discussion. Cobblestone has a wall, but regular stone dors not. Purpur has a pillar, and a nice one at that, but not a wall.
Agreed. Prismarine bricks also need walls, and dark prismarine, cut sandstone/red sandstone, calcite, tuff, and regular stone.
Just more block parity in general. Think we're asking for variants: Wall, Polished, Smooth, Stair, Slab. Came here cuz no polished diorite wall for some reason.
Yeah that makes sense I think this would be good
Based.
Fully rusted iron golems should be ignored by mobs. Maybe you can find them naturally in zombie villages?

Rusted iron golems (which would then break and disappear/despawn) would be interesting! Would add a sort of cap to how many iron golems can wander around a lit village, since well-lit and/or walled villages tend to get a bit crowded with them.
That makes a lot of sense!
Yeah! I like this!

Bro I legitimately thought you had the same idea I had since instead of having coal and bones separate why not combine them together and use them how we use coal, and your idea can work as well too since all I thought of is combining the coal and bones together

Trains already exist. A furnace in a minecart can pull up to four other minecarts of any kind. What trains need is to be stronger; trains are so fragile, they break when they go around corners, rendering them basically useless.
As the other person said, "trains already exist" no they do not, there is no way to connect minecrats. ü§® silly
There needs to be a better way to transport them. The bottle is a really good idea. I hope this gets added into the game
I never did see the point of the Allay, but I can definitely get behind people who want them being able to compactly transport them.
